com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure

Class FloatColors

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.FloatColors

  • public class FloatColors
extends java.lang.Object
    Various utility methods for working with colors encoded as packed floats in any of the formats this can use.
    Created by Tommy Ettinger on 12/2/2019.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      FloatColors()

      static float hsl2rgb(float hsla)
      Converts a packed float in HSLA format (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha) to a packed float in RGBA format.

      Converts the four HSLA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to a packed float in RGBA format.

      Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change.
      static float lerpFloatColorsBlended(float start, float end, float change)
      Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change, but keeps the alpha of start and uses the alpha of end as an extra factor that can affect how much to change.

      Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure.

      Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure.

      Returns a 1:1 mix of color0 and color1.
      static float mix(float color0, float color1, float color2)
      Returns a 1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, and color2.
      static float mix(float color0, float color1, float color2, float color3)
      Returns a 1:1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, color2, and color3.
      static float multiplyAlpha(float encodedColor, float alpha)
      Given a color stored as a packed float and an alpha multiplier to affect that color (between 0f and 1f, inclusive and clamped in that range), this makes a packed float color that has the same red, green, and blue channels but has its own alpha multiplied by alpha, without constructing any objects along the way.
      static float rgb2hsl(float rgba)
      Converts a packed float in RGBA format to a packed float in "HSLA format" (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha), which isn't one of the regular formats this supports but can be useful for conversions.
      static float rgb2hsl(float r, float g, float b, float a)
      Converts the four RGBA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to a packed float in "HSLA format" (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha), which isn't one of the regular formats this supports but can be useful for conversions.
      static float setAlpha(float encodedColor, float alpha)
      Given a color stored as a packed float, and a desired alpha to set for that color (between 0.0 and 1.0, inclusive and clamped in that range), this makes a new float that has the same red, green, and blue channels but has been set to the given alpha, without constructing any objects along the way.

      • hsl2rgb

        public static float hsl2rgb(float hsla)
        Converts a packed float in HSLA format (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha) to a packed float in RGBA format.
        Parameters:
        hsla - an HSLA-format packed float
        Returns:
        an RGBA-format packed float

      • hsl2rgb

        public static float hsl2rgb(float h,
                            float s,
                            float l,
                            float a)
        Converts the four HSLA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to a packed float in RGBA format.
        Parameters:
        h - hue, from 0.0 to 1.0
        s - saturation, from 0.0 to 1.0
        l - lightness, from 0.0 to 1.0
        a - alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
        Returns:
        an RGBA-format packed float

      • rgb2hsl

        public static float rgb2hsl(float rgba)
        Converts a packed float in RGBA format to a packed float in "HSLA format" (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha), which isn't one of the regular formats this supports but can be useful for conversions.
        Parameters:
        rgba - an RGBA-format packed float
        Returns:
        an "HSLA-format" packed float

      • rgb2hsl

        public static float rgb2hsl(float r,
                            float g,
                            float b,
                            float a)
        Converts the four RGBA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to a packed float in "HSLA format" (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha), which isn't one of the regular formats this supports but can be useful for conversions.
        Parameters:
        r - red, from 0.0 to 1.0
        g - green, from 0.0 to 1.0
        b - blue, from 0.0 to 1.0
        a - alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
        Returns:
        an "HSLA-format" packed float

      • multiplyAlpha

        public static float multiplyAlpha(float encodedColor,
                                  float alpha)
        Given a color stored as a packed float and an alpha multiplier to affect that color (between 0f and 1f, inclusive and clamped in that range), this makes a packed float color that has the same red, green, and blue channels but has its own alpha multiplied by alpha, without constructing any objects along the way. If you want to set the alpha without considering its current value, you can use setAlpha(float, float)
        Parameters:
        encodedColor - a color encoded as a packed float, as by ColorTools.ycwcm(float, float, float, float) or ColorTools.ipt(float, float, float, float)
        alpha - between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive, the alpha to multiply the color's own alpha by
        Returns:
        a color encoded as a packed float, using color's RGB channels but with its A channel times alpha

      • setAlpha

        public static float setAlpha(float encodedColor,
                             float alpha)
        Given a color stored as a packed float, and a desired alpha to set for that color (between 0.0 and 1.0, inclusive and clamped in that range), this makes a new float that has the same red, green, and blue channels but has been set to the given alpha, without constructing any objects along the way. This does not consider the current alpha of the encoded color; if you want to do that, you can use multiplyAlpha(float, float).
        Parameters:
        encodedColor - a color encoded as a packed float, as by ColorTools.ycwcm(float, float, float, float) or ColorTools.ipt(float, float, float, float)
        alpha - between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive, the alpha to set into the returned packed color
        Returns:
        another color encoded as a packed float, using encodedColor's RGB channels and the given alpha

      • lerpFloatColors

        public static float lerpFloatColors(float start,
                                    float end,
                                    float change)
        Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change. Both start and end should be packed colors, as from ColorTools.ycwcm(float, float, float, float) or ColorTools.ipt(float, float, float, float), and change can be between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use end). Both start and end should use the same color space; that is, both could be produced using YCwCm, both could be produced using IPT, or both could be libGDX-native RGB, but they can't mix. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors.
        Parameters:
        start - the starting color as a packed float
        end - the target color as a packed float
        change - how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
        Returns:
        a packed float that represents a color between start and end

      • lerpFloatColorsBlended

        public static float lerpFloatColorsBlended(float start,
                                           float end,
                                           float change)
        Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change, but keeps the alpha of start and uses the alpha of end as an extra factor that can affect how much to change. Both start and end should be packed colors, as from ColorTools.ycwcm(float, float, float, float) or ColorTools.ipt(float, float, float, float), and change can be between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use end). Both start and end should use the same color space; that is, both could be produced using YCwCm, or both could be produced using IPT, but not a mix of the two. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors.
        Parameters:
        start - the starting color as a packed float; alpha will be preserved
        end - the target color as a packed float; alpha will not be used directly, and will instead be multiplied with change
        change - how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
        Returns:
        a packed float that represents a color between start and end

      • mix

        public static float mix(float color0,
                        float color1)
        Returns a 1:1 mix of color0 and color1. All colors should use the same color space. This is the same as calling lerpFloatColors(float, float, float) with a change of 0.5.
        Parameters:
        color0 - the first color to mix, as a packed float color
        color1 - the second color to mix, as a packed float color
        Returns:
        an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color

      • mix

        public static float mix(float color0,
                        float color1,
                        float color2)
        Returns a 1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, and color2. All colors should use the same color space.
        Parameters:
        color0 - the first color to mix, as a packed float color
        color1 - the second color to mix, as a packed float color
        color2 - the third color to mix, as a packed float color
        Returns:
        an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color

      • mix

        public static float mix(float color0,
                        float color1,
                        float color2,
                        float color3)
        Returns a 1:1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, color2, and color3. All colors should use the same color space.
        Parameters:
        color0 - the first color to mix, as a packed float color
        color1 - the second color to mix, as a packed float color
        color2 - the third color to mix, as a packed float color
        color3 - the fourth color to mix, as a packed float color
        Returns:
        an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color

      • mix

        public static float mix(float... colors)
        Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure. If colors is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
        Parameters:
        colors - an array or varargs of packed float colors; all should use the same color space
        Returns:
        an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color

      • mix

        public static float mix(float[] colors,
                        int offset,
                        int size)
        Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure. If colors is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
        Parameters:
        colors - an array or varargs of packed float colors; all should use the same color space
        offset - the index of the first item in colors to use
        size - how many items from colors to use
        Returns:
        an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
